text: hi everyone thomas joseph here now
frittatas are the easy to make Italian
version of a French omelet they're
inexpensive to make you can use
leftovers and they're quick cooking but
a lot of people have trouble with
frittatas because they become either
overcooked or they're too watery so
today I'm going to share with you some
tricks and techniques in making a
foolproof for tot up the first trick is
that you have to have cooked ingredients
that you're going to put into your
frittata so today I'm using onions and a
mixture of zucchini and summer squash to
start I have a 10-inch nonstick skillet
one tablespoon of unsalted butter I have
one onion that's thinly sliced and get
those cooking and that'll take about two
minutes until the onions are translucent
and have cooked down slightly you want
to make sure that you're not adding raw
vegetables directly to your frittata
otherwise you're going to end up with a
watery frittata so you get to cook out
that moisture and you want to make sure
that you use cheeses that are a little
lower in moisture so the onions are nice
and translucent and soft add one and a
half cups of summer squash that is
halved lengthwise and cut into
quarter-inch slices cook this for about
three to four minutes until the zucchini
and the summer squash gets slightly
Brown and soft so the vegetables have
cooked down you can see the volume is
much much less and that means that all
of that moisture has been cooked out
which is perfect for our frittata so I
have 12 large eggs in a large bowl add a
quarter of a cup of heavy cream which
adds wonderful richness here you don't
want too much dairy again not too much
moisture it'll toughen up the eggs and
make them watery whisk this together
gently now you don't want to over beat
the eggs here because what that does is
it creates volume here and when you cook
it it collapses so you will not end up
with a fluffy frittata two tablespoons
of chopped fresh chives and four basil
leaves which have been cut into a nice
Shifa not so gently mix that in
in the mixture with salt and pepper very
important you need to season all of
those eggs whisk enough to combine the
ingredients but not to incorporate the
air make sure that your temperature is
medium heat because we don't want to
cook this on high high heat we want it
to be a gentle cooking process and what
you want to do is gently pull some of
the egg mixture into the middle and what
this does is it creates a really fluffy
frittata because what you're doing is
you're creating large curds within the
frittata itself and you will end up with
a batata that cooks more evenly and much
faster so it's less about stirring more
about kind of gently shifting the eggs
in and around the pan make sure you
pre-heat your broiler to high and have a
rack situated in the upper part of the
oven because we're going to finish this
frittata in the oven so you can see that
the top is still a little loose and
runny but the bottom is quite set so
this is the perfect time to now add the
cheese 1/2 cup of grated Parmesan cheese
it's a low moisture cheese it has a
really pungent flavor so you really
don't have to use that much but you
really get a great payoff in terms of
the flavor so sprinkle that over the top
and 3 ounces of fresh goat cheese now
we're not using too much of this because
it is high in moisture so dot this
around the top of the frittata and this
is going right into the oven under the
broiler for about a minute to two
minutes so watch it closely and make
sure your table is set because this is
gonna be delicious hot out of the oven
so as you can see the patata is
beautiful it's nicely puffed and it's
golden there's no excess moisture and if
you follow these tricks techniques and
tips you will have success every single
time you make a frittata
enjoy
you
